item.title: Canada’s National Forest Inventory (NFI) – Forest Composition across Canada
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
Canada’s National Forest Inventory (NFI) sampling program supports reporting on forests at the national scale, as well as supporting strategic analyses of regional policy and management issues through continuous development of maps of forest attributes. Overall, these new products provide unique baseline information for strategic-level analyses of forest: nfi.nfis.org. Time Period From: 2001To: 2006 Geographic […]

The post Canada’s National Forest Inventory (NFI) – Forest Composition across Canada appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
Canada’s National Forest Inventory (NFI) sampling program supports reporting on forests at the national scale, as well as supporting strategic analyses of regional policy and management issues through continuous development of maps of forest attributes. Overall, these new products provide unique baseline information for strategic-level analyses of forest: nfi.nfis.org.

Time Period
From: 2001
To: 2006

Geographic Extent
SW: -141 41.68
NE: -52.62 83.11

Read more

The maps have been produced covering 4.03 × 106 km2 of inventoried forest area for the 2001 base year using standardised observations from the NFI photo plots (PP) as reference data. The k nearest neighbours (kNN) method was used with 26 geospatial data layers including MODIS spectral data and climatic and topographic variables to produce maps of 127 forest attributes at a 250 × 250 m resolution.

The stand-level attributes include land cover, structure, and tree species relative abundance. In this article, we report only on total live aboveground tree biomass, with all other attributes covered in the supplementary data (nrcresearchpress.com). In general, deviations in predicted pixel-level values from those in a PP validation set are greater in mountainous regions and in areas with either low biomass or sparse PP sampling. Predicted pixel-level values are overestimated at small observed values and underestimated at large ones. Accuracy measures are improved through the spatial aggregation of pixels to 1 km2 and beyond.

Geographic Information

kNN Dominant Genus 250 meter
kNN Dominant Genus 250 meter

Data Contact

 

Organization:

 

Government of Canada; Natural Resources Canada; Canadian Forest Service (CFS)

This dataset has been confirmed to be foundationally important to Canada and Canadians.

The post Canada’s National Forest Inventory (NFI) – Forest Composition across Canada appeared first on GEO.CA.

item.title: Major Projects Inventory
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
The major projects inventory provides a snapshot of major natural resource projects currently under construction or for which construction is planned to be initiated in the next 10 years. The inventory includes major projects that increase, extend or improve natural resource production in Canada, including new extraction projects, infrastructure projects and major processing facilities. Large […]

The post Major Projects Inventory appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
The major projects inventory provides a snapshot of major natural resource projects currently under construction or for which construction is planned to be initiated in the next 10 years. The inventory includes major projects that increase, extend or improve natural resource production in Canada, including new extraction projects, infrastructure projects and major processing facilities. Large expansion projects are also included in the inventory.

Time Period
From: 2019
To: 

Geographic Extent
SW: -141 41.68
NE: -52.64 83.34

Read more

Projects are represented either by points or lines. The user must consult both point and line geometries to have the complete projects inventory.

DISCLAIMER: Data is sourced from federal, provincial, and territorial databases, publicly accessible websites, and other sources, including CANOILS. Data and maps are for illustrative purposes only. Users understand that, although all efforts have been made to accurately and exhaustively compile, locate and classify projects, the authors do not guarantee the accuracy and/or the comprehensiveness of the data and assume no responsibility for errors or omissions. The routes of the proposed transmission lines and pipelines are approximations, often using only start and end points. In support of this initiative, proponents and partners are encouraged to contact Natural Resources Canada should they identify any significant errors or omissions.

Geographic Information

Major Projects Inventory
Major Projects Inventory

item.title: River Ice State in Canada – Cartographic Product Collection
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
Collection of monitoring products of river ice roughness from current and past winter seasons throughout Canada as monitored by Natural Resources Canada using satellite imagery. This collection of cartographic products regroups river ice state monitoring products and their associated footprints. Three visualization timeframes are available: Active Monitoring of River Ice in Canada View Map 2. […]

The post River Ice State in Canada – Cartographic Product Collection appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
Collection of monitoring products of river ice roughness from current and past winter seasons throughout Canada as monitored by Natural Resources Canada using satellite imagery.

This collection of cartographic products regroups river ice state monitoring products and their associated footprints. Three visualization timeframes are available:

  1. Active Monitoring of River Ice in Canada
View Map

2. River Ice in Canada – Current Year

View Map

3. River Ice in Canada – Archive

View Map

Time Period
From: 2011-04-04
To: 

Geographic Extent
SW: -141 41.68
NE: -52.62 83.11

item.title: National Hydro Network – NHN – GeoBase Series
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
The National Hydro Network (NHN) focuses on providing a quality geometric description and a set of basic attributes describing Canada’s inland surface waters. The best available federal and provincial data are used for its production, which is done jointly by federal, and interested provincial and territorial partners. The data has a great potential for analysis, […]

The post National Hydro Network – NHN – GeoBase Series appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
The National Hydro Network (NHN) focuses on providing a quality geometric description and a set of basic attributes describing Canada’s inland surface waters. The best available federal and provincial data are used for its production, which is done jointly by federal, and interested provincial and territorial partners. The data has a great potential for analysis, cartographic representation and display, and serves as base data in many applications.

Time Period
From: 1944
To: 

Geographic Extent
SW: -141 42
NE: -43 84

Read more

The NHN is created from existing data at the 1:50 000 scale or better. It provides geospatial digital data compliant with the NHN Standard such as lakes, reservoirs, watercourses (rivers and streams), canals, islands, drainage linear network, toponyms or geographical names, constructions and obstacles related to surface waters, etc. The NHN Work Unit Limits were created based on Water Survey of Canada Sub-Sub-Drainage Area.

Geographic Information

National Hydro Network - NHN - GeoBase Series
National Hydro Network - NHN - GeoBase Series

item.title: Soil Landscapes of Canada Version 3.2
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
The “Soil Landscapes of Canada (SLC) Version 3.2” dataset series provides a set of geo-referenced soil areas, linked to a series of attribute data, which together describe the spatial distribution of soil and associated landscapes of the agricultural areas of Canada Time Period From: 2013-01-01To:  Geographic ExtentSW: -132 36NE: -52 90 Read more The soil […]

The post Soil Landscapes of Canada Version 3.2 appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
The “Soil Landscapes of Canada (SLC) Version 3.2” dataset series provides a set of geo-referenced soil areas, linked to a series of attribute data, which together describe the spatial distribution of soil and associated landscapes of the agricultural areas of Canada

Time Period
From: 2013-01-01
To: 

Geographic Extent
SW: -132 36
NE: -52 90

Read more

The soil areas (polygons) are linked to attribute data found in the associated Component Table (CMP), Component Rating Table (CRT), Soil Names Table (SNT), Soil Layer Table (SLT), Landscape Segmentation Table (LST), Landform Extent Table (LET), Landform Definition Table and Ecological Framework Table (EFT). However, some provinces (Alberta, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island) contain CMP, SNT and SLT data for the entire province (that is, beyond the agricultural areas). This version is complemented by the previous SLC version 2.2, which covers the entire country.

Geographic Information

Data Contact

 

Organization:

 

Government of Canada; Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada; Science and Technology Branch

 

Email:

infocansis@agr.gc.ca

Share on email

Share on twitter
Share on linkedin

This dataset has been confirmed to be foundationally important to Canada and Canadians.

item.title: Detailed Soil Survey
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
Soil surveys have been published for most agricultural areas, and many surrounding areas, across Canada. Data from these surveys comprise the most detailed soil inventory information in the National Soil Database (NSDB). A soil survey is an inventory of soils and their spatial distribution over a landscape. Detailed soil survey information is much more accurate […]

The post Detailed Soil Survey appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
Soil surveys have been published for most agricultural areas, and many surrounding areas, across Canada. Data from these surveys comprise the most detailed soil inventory information in the National Soil Database (NSDB).

A soil survey is an inventory of soils and their spatial distribution over a landscape. Detailed soil survey information is much more accurate and reliable for making decisions at the farm-level.

Time Period
From: 2013-01-01
To:

Geographic Extent
SW: -147.57 39.29
NE: -29.68 67.38

Read more

Soil survey reports contain two parts. The first part is a soil map or series of maps at a particular scale with coding for each soil. The reports also include a supporting document that contains background information such as how the soil survey was conducted, an explanation of interpretive criteria, and a summary of the area occupied by various soil types.

The detailed soil surveys identify more of the variation in soil types across smaller landscapes, as compared to Generalized (1:100 000, i.e. provincial overview) and Reconnaissance or General (1:125 000, or 1/2 inch to 1 mile.) soil surveys. Version 3 was created by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada in the 2010’s by amalgamating version 2 data. It introduced some minor refinements to the version 2 data structure to provide closer alignment with the Soil Landscapes of Canada data structure.

Geographic Information

Data Contact

 

Organization:

 

Government of Canada; Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada; Science and Technology Branch

 

Email:

 

infocansis@agr.gc.ca

Share on email

item.title: Surficial Geology
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
The surficial geology dataset is a collection of individually published maps across Canada. The collection provides a national surficial geological framework and the maps are in a standardized format for all users. Three types of maps are available: Surficial Geology View Map 2. Reconnaissance Surficial Geology View Map 3. Predictive Surficial Geology View Map Time […]

The post Surficial Geology appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
The surficial geology dataset is a collection of individually published maps across Canada. The collection provides a national surficial geological framework and the maps are in a standardized format for all users.

Three types of maps are available:

  1. Surficial Geology
View Map

2. Reconnaissance Surficial Geology

View Map

3. Predictive Surficial Geology

View Map

Time Period
From: 2014
To: 

Geographic Extent
SW: -141 41.68
NE: -52.62 83.11

Read more

The maps are published using the Canadian Geoscience Map Series Format. Three types of maps are available:

1) Surficial Geology: based on expert-knowledge full air photo interpretation (may include interpretive satellite imagery, Digital Elevation Models (DEM)), incorporating field data and ground truthing resulting from extensive, systematic fieldwork across the entire map area. Air photo interpretation includes map unit/deposit genesis, texture, thickness, structure, morphology, depositional or erosional environment, ice flow or meltwater direction, age/cross-cutting relationships, landscape evolution and associated geological features, complemented by additional overlay modifiers, points and linear features, selected from over 275 different geological elements in the Surficial Data Model. Wherever possible, legacy data is also added to the map.

2) Reconnaissance Surficial Geology: based on expert-knowledge full air photo interpretation (may include interpretive satellite imagery, DEMs), with limited or no fieldwork. Air photo interpretation includes map unit/deposit genesis, texture, thickness, structure, morphology, depositional or erosional environment, ice flow or meltwater direction, age/cross-cutting relationships, landscape evolution and associated geological features, complemented by additional overlay modifiers, points and linear features, selected from over 275 different geological elements in the Surficial Data Model. Wherever possible, legacy data is also added to the map.

3) Predictive Surficial Geology: derived from one or more methods of remote predictive mapping (RPM) using different satellite imagery, spectral characteristics of vegetation and surface moisture, machine processing, algorithms etc., DEMs, where raster data are converted to vector, with some expert-knowledge air photo interpretation (training areas or post-verification areas), varying degrees of non-systematic fieldwork, and the addition of any legacy data available.

Each map was created with a specific extent or scale which may result in data superimposition. These maps share a common science language (common legend) based on the Geological Survey of Canada’s Surficial Data Model.

Geographic Information

Surficial Geology
Surficial Geology

Data Contact

 

Organization:

 

Government of Canada; Natural Resources Canada; Earth Sciences Sector; Geological Survey of Canada

 

Email:

NRCan.Geoinfo.RNCan@Canada.ca

Share on email
Share on facebook
Share on twitter
Share on linkedin

This dataset has been confirmed to be foundationally important to Canada and Canadians.

The post Surficial Geology appeared first on GEO.CA.

item.title: Floods in Canada – Cartographic Product Collection
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
Natural Resource Canada’s Emergency Geomatics Services provide ice break-up and flood event information. “Floods in Canada” provide a collection of products for active and past floods as monitored by Natural Resources Canada using satellite imagery for emergency response. This collection of cartographic products regroups flood extent polygons and their associated footprints. Three visualization timeframes are […]

The post Floods in Canada – Cartographic Product Collection appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
Natural Resource Canada’s Emergency Geomatics Services provide ice break-up and flood event information. “Floods in Canada” provide a collection of products for active and past floods as monitored by Natural Resources Canada using satellite imagery for emergency response.

This collection of cartographic products regroups flood extent polygons and their associated footprints. Three visualization timeframes are available:

  1.  Active Floods in Canada
View Map

2.  Floods in Canada – Current Year

View Map

3.  Floods in Canada – Archive

View Map

Time Period
From: 2011-04-04
To:

Geographic Extent
SW: -141 41.68
NE: -52.62 83.11

item.title: Canadian Digital Elevation Model, 1945-2011
item.dc:creator: Christopher Melnick-Macdonald
item.description:
PRODUCT USE: This collection is a legacy product that is no longer supported. It may not meet current government standards. The Canadian Digital Elevation Model (CDEM) is part of Natural Resources Canada’s altimetry system designed to better meet needs for elevation data and products. It stemmed from the archived Canadian Digital Elevation Data (CDED) in […]

The post Canadian Digital Elevation Model, 1945-2011 appeared first on GEO.CA.
item.content:encoded:
PRODUCT USE: This collection is a legacy product that is no longer supported. It may not meet current government standards.

The Canadian Digital Elevation Model (CDEM) is part of Natural Resources Canada’s altimetry system designed to better meet needs for elevation data and products.

It stemmed from the archived Canadian Digital Elevation Data (CDED) in which elevations were either ground or reflective surface elevations.

Time Period
From: 1945
To: 2011

Geographic Extent
SW: -142 41
NE: -52 84

Read more

The pre-packaged GeoTiff datasets are based on the National Topographic System of Canada (NTS) at the 1:250 000 scale; the NTS index file is available in the Resources section (through the dataset link below) in many formats.

The Geospatial Data Extraction Tool allows the user to obtain a CDEM mosaic for a pre-defined or user-defined extent. The coverage and resolution of a mosaic varies according to latitude and to the extent of the requested area. Derived products such as slope, shaded relief and colour-shaded relief maps can also be generated on demand.

Geographic Information

Canadian Digital Elevation Model, Color Shaded Relief
Canadian Digital Elevation Model, Color Shaded Relief

Data Contact

 

Organization:

 

Government of Canada; Natural Resources Canada; Strategic Policy and Results Sector; Canada Centre for Mapping and Earth Observation
